feedback.Physical object: Excluded — The contract is an abstract agreement, even if instantiated on paper or screen.
feedback.Man-made / synthetic: Excluded — While drafted by humans, its identity is not based on material fabrication.
feedback.Biological or biologically-inspired: Excluded — It is not derived from biological systems.
feedback.Fixed/static: Excluded — Terms can be amended or renegotiated.
feedback.Structural: Excluded — It is not a physical or architectural structure.
feedback.Perceptible: Excluded — The content can be read, but the contract as a semantic entity is abstract.
feedback.Material form: Excluded — Instantiated via documents, but not materially defined.
feedback.Passive: Excluded — It imposes obligations and grants rights; not passive.
feedback.Purposeful / intentional: Included — Created deliberately to define working relationships and obligations.
feedback.Emits output / produces effect: Excluded — It does not generate output directly, though it has legal effects.
feedback.Transforms or modifies internal state: Excluded — Relies on parties for enforcement and interpretation.
feedback.Interacts with humans directly: Excluded — Not an interface, but a formalized agreement.
feedback.Part of a larger system: Included — Exists within legal, corporate, and labor systems.
feedback.Autonomous in function: Excluded — Dependent on recognition and enforcement.
feedback.System-critical: Excluded — Important, but not essential to the operation of all systems.
feedback.Symbolic / representational: Included — Encodes mutual obligations and roles.
feedback.Communicative: Excluded — Communicates indirectly through format, but not communicative in structure.
feedback.Logical / rule-based: Included — Expresses rules, obligations, and permissions.
feedback.Hierarchical / modular: Excluded — Often structured, but not intrinsically modular.
feedback.Behavior-guiding: Included — Directs permissible and expected actions.
feedback.Self-referential / meta-conceptual: Excluded — Not self-reflective or modeling higher-order concepts.
feedback.Temporal: Excluded — May reference durations but not inherently temporal.
feedback.Contextual abstraction: Included — Only meaningful within legal, cultural, and organizational context.
feedback.Socially / culturally constructed: Included — Rooted in societal norms and employment law.
feedback.Defined by a group/system: Included — Shaped and enforced by employers, legal institutions, and labor bodies.
feedback.Linked to identity or role: Included — Defines an individual’s formal occupational role.
feedback.Regulated / governed: Included — Subject to labor law, policy, and enforcement mechanisms.
feedback.Teachable / transmissible: Included — Understood through professional norms, training, and education.
feedback.Visible: Included — Formally shared, archived, or disclosed.
feedback.Context-sensitive: Included — Its interpretation depends on institutional, legal, and cultural setting.
feedback.Widely known: Included — Employment contracts are universally recognized structures.

encoding_notes: This encoding models the employment contract as an abstract, symbolic, rule-based social artifact situated within legal and institutional frameworks. It defines roles and behaviors without being a physical or autonomous agent. The corrected code '0084A9FF' reflects its rule-governed, identity-defining, and socially embedded nature.
